definition:
```
Turing Machine:
A Turing Machine is a theoretical machine thought of by Alan Turing that can simulate any set of instructions given to it. It is made of 3 main parts:
- Infinite Tape: it can store inputs, outputs, and intermediate data. It's just an infinite memory unit.
- The head: it can read and write data to and from the tape, and move the tape 1 cell to the left or right.
- State Register: stores the state of the machine, and tells it what to do based on a set of rules.

Note that a turing machine can only change 1 bit at a time, which makes it the simplest, and yet very tricky, machine that can simulate literally anything, given the time and space.
```
```
Turing Complete:

When a machine is "Turing Complete", it can simulate a Turing Machine. This means it can do these things:
- change data based on a set of rules.
- save data to (theoretically infinite) memory.
- loop a series of actions/instructions.
- change the way it executes something based on a set of rules, aka conditions.
- and simply be able to execute a series of 'instructions' without external support.
Once a machine can do those things, it is considered "Turing Complete", and can theoretically simulate ANYTHING given the time and resources.```

CPUs are good examples of Turing Complete machines.
